case_name: Amritsar Distillery Co. Ltd. v. Union of India

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 119 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 119 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated June 16, 1953, of Punjab High Court in Civil Reference No. 1 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal from the judgment and order dated June 16, 1953, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Reference No. 1 of 1953.

facts.text: Appellant is a company carrying on business as a distiller of country liquor.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-The appellant is a companypany carrying on business as a distiller of companyntry liquor.

facts.text: Appellant incorporated in May 1945 as reconstruction of previously existing Amritsar Distillery Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: It was incorporated in May 1945 and was in fact a previously existing companypany called the Amritsar Distillery Co. Ltd. reconstructed under the provisions of the Companys Act.

facts.text: Appellant carried on same business as predecessor: sale of distillery produce to licensed wholesalers.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant carried on the same business as its predecessor, namely, sale of the produce of its distillery to licensed wholesalers.

facts.text: Government devised buy-back scheme in 1940 to relieve scarcity of bottles after war started.

anchor.surface_text: After the war started the demand for companyntry liquor increased but difficulty was felt in finding bottles in which the liquor was to be sold. In order to relieve the scarcity of bottles the Government devised in 1940 a scheme called the buy-back scheme.

facts.text: Buy-back scheme: distiller entitled to charge wholesaler fixed price for bottles, repay on return.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme in substance was that a distiller on a sale of liquor became entitled to charge a wholesaler a price for the bottles in which the liquor was supplied at rates fixed by the Government which he was bound to repay to the wholesaler on the latter returning the bottles.

facts.text: Sometime in 1944, Amritsar Distillery Co. Ltd. insisted on wholesalers paying additional security deposits per bottle besides buy-back price.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in 1944, the Amritsar Distillery Co. Ltd. which then was in existence, insisted on the wholesalers paying to it in addition to the price of the bottles fixed under the buy-back scheme, certain amounts described as security deposits and calculated at varying rates per bottle according to sizes

facts.text: Security deposits promised to be refunded per bottle returned, full amount when 90% of bottles covered returned.

anchor.surface_text: for the bottles in which the liquor was supplied to them promising to pay back for each bottle returned at the rate applicable to it and further promising to pay back the entire amount paid on a transaction when 90 per cent. of the bottles companyered by it had been returned.

facts.text: Appellant realized these additional sums after taking over the business.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany while it was in existence realised these additional sums and so did the appellant after it took over the business.

facts.text: Object of additional sums: additional inducement for return of bottles to distiller.

anchor.surface_text: The object of demanding and taking these additional sums was obviously to provide additional inducement for the return of the bottles to the distiller so that its trade in selling the produce of its distillery might number be hampered for want of bottles.

facts.text: No time limit fixed for bottles return to entitle wholesaler to refund; no refund ever refused.

anchor.surface_text: No time limit had been fixed within which the bottles had to be returned in order to entitle a wholesaler to the refund, number does it appear that a refund had ever been refused.

facts.text: Buy-back bottle price entered in general trading account; additional sums in Empty Bottles Return Security Deposit Account.

anchor.surface_text: The price of the bottles received by the appellant under the buy-back scheme was entered by it in its general trading account while the additional sum received for them was entered in the general ledger under the heading Empty Bottles Return Security Deposit Account .

facts.text: Additional amounts taken without Government's sanction and as condition imposed by appellant itself for sale of liquor. Not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that for the accounting periods with which this case is companycerned, the additional amounts had been taken without Governments sanction and entirely as a companydition imposed by the appellant itself for the sale of its liquor.

facts.text: Appellant assessed to income-tax on balance of additional sums after refunds.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was assessed to income-tax on the balance of the amounts of these additional sums left after the refunds made there out.

facts.text: Appellant also assessed to business profits tax and excess profits tax on same balance.

anchor.surface_text: It had also been assessed to business profits tax and excess profits tax on the same balance.

facts.text: Appellant's appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Tribunal failed.

anchor.surface_text: Its appeals against the orders of assessment to these taxes to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and thereafter to the Tribunal failed.

facts.text: High Court referred question: Whether collections described as empty bottle return security deposits were income assessable under section 10 of Income-tax Act? Answered affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: It then obtained an order referring a certain question arising out of the assessments for decision by the High Court of Punjab. ... The High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal against High Court decision on all three taxes.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is against that decision which related to all the three varieties of taxes for which the appellant had been made liable.

facts.text: In each sale, appellant took liquor price, govt bottle price, and security deposit; would not sell without all.

anchor.surface_text: The sale was made on these terms In each transaction of sale the appellant took from the wholesaler the price of the liquor, a certain sum fixed by the government, as price of the bottles in which the liquor was supplied and a further sum described as security deposit for the return of the bottles.

facts.text: Bottle price returned as bottles returned; security deposit full when 90% bottles returned.

anchor.surface_text: The moneys taken as price of the bottles were returned as and when the bottles were returned. The moneys described as security deposit were also returned as and when the bottles were returned with only this difference that in this case the entire sum taken in one transaction was refunded when 90 per cent. of the bottles companyered by it had been returned,

facts.text: Court finding: additional sums are trading receipts, part of consideration for sale of bottled liquor.

anchor.surface_text: Such being the nature of the appellants trade and the manner in which it was companyducted, these additional sums appear to us to be its trading receipts. ... So the amount which was called security deposit was actually a -part of the companysideration for the sale and therefore part of the price of what was sold.

facts.text: No obligation on wholesalers to return bottles; no right to their return.

anchor.surface_text: There companyld be numbersecurity given for the return of the bottles unless there was a right to their return for if there was numbersuch right, there would be numberhing to secure. Now we find numbertrace of such a right in the statement of the care. The wholesalers were clearly under numberobligation to return the bottles.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds security deposits are trading receipts assessable to tax; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Having given the matter our anxious companysideration which the difficulties involved in it require, we think that the companyrect view to take is that the amounts paid to the appellant and described as Empty Bottles Return Security Deposit were trading receipts and therefore income of the appellant assessable to tax.
section 10 of the Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: reconstructed under the provisions of the Companies Act.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the collections by the assessee company described in its accounts as empty bottle return security deposits were income assessable under section 10 of the Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the collections by the assessee company described in its accounts as empty bottle return security deposits were income assessable under section 10 of the

issues.text: whether these amounts called security deposits were trading receipts

anchor.surface_text: the question is whether these amounts called security deposits were trading receipts.

arguments.claim: The additional sums could not be regarded as price because the price of the bottles was separately fixed under the buy-back scheme and the deposit was different from and exclusive of it

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Vishwanatha Sastri appearing on behalf of the appellant first contended that on these facts the amounts could not be regarded as price and that therefore they were not trading receipts. He said that the price of the bottles was separately fixed and the amount taken as deposit was different from and exclusive of, it. This contention is founded on the use of the word price in the buy-back scheme in connection with the rates which the distiller was entitled to charge a wholesaler for the bottles.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: atement of the care. The wholesalers were clearly under numberobligation to return the bottles. The only thing that Mr. Sastri companyld point out for

arguments.court_reasoning: Undue emphasis on word 'price'; actually part of consideration for sale of bottled liquor as appellant would not sell without it; High Court view correct that it was extra price for bottles

arguments.claim: The additional sums were deposits securing the return of the bottles and therefore not trading receipts

anchor.surface_text: Now, if these additional sums were not part of the price, what were they? Mr. Sastri said that they were deposits securing the return of the bottles. According to him if they were such security deposits, they were not trading receipts. Again we are unable to agree.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er think that case assists at all. What had happened there was that the Shell Company had appointed a large number of agents in China to sell its prod

arguments.court_reasoning: No security without right to return bottles; no trace of such obligation on wholesalers; words 'security deposit' alone insufficient to create obligation; no time limit for return indicates no obligation

arguments.claim: The additional sums are like deposits in Davies v. The Shell Company of China Ltd., which were not trading receipts

anchor.surface_text: For this part of the case Mr. Sastri relied on Davies v. The Shell Company of China Ltd., but we do not think that case assists at all. What had happened there was that the Shell Company had appointed a large number of agents in China to sell its products and had taken from each agent a deposit to secure itself against the risk of default by the agent duly to account for the sale proceeds.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: his appointment has deposited with or, in other words, lent to the companypany the amount of his stipulated deposit. lie also said at p. 156 it If the

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished because Shell deposits were anterior to trading transactions, part of trading structure, like loans; here amounts part of each trading transaction, essential as no sale without them

arguments.claim: Even if the amounts were securities deposited for the return of the bottles, they would still be trading receipts as part of trading transactions necessary to carry on trade

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sanyal was prepared to argue that even if the amounts were securities deposited for the return of the bottles, they would still be trading receipts, for they were part of the trading transactions and the return of the bottles was necessary to enable the appellant to carry on its trade, namely, to sell liquor in them.

arguments.claim: The additional sums are trading receipts as they are part of the consideration for the sale of bottled liquor

anchor.surface_text: Such being the nature of the appellants trade and the manner in which it was conducted, these additional sums appear to us to be its trading receipts. ... So the amount which was called security deposit was actually a part of the consideration for the sale and therefore part of the price of what was sold.

arguments.claim: The case is analogous to the second arrangement in K. M. S. Lakshmanier Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax where initial payments were trading receipts, not security deposits

anchor.surface_text: The case nearest to the present one is, in our view, that decided by this Court in K. M. S. Lakshmanier Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax... It seems to us that the amounts involved in the present case were exactly of the nature of the deposits made in the second period in Lakshmanier Sons case.

arguments.claim: The present case does not fall within the third arrangement in Lakshmanier Sons case where deposits were loans

anchor.surface_text: It was Mr. Sastris effort to bring the case within the arrangement that prevailed in the third part of the accounting period in Laskhmanier Sons case, the initial payments made during which were held to be loans. But we think that he has not succeeded in this.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: anylateral companytract invest the deposit with a different character. It remains a loan of which the repayment in full is companyditioned by the due

arguments.court_reasoning: Here amount related to price of goods sold, condition of each sale, refundable per transaction; unlike third period deposit once for all, anterior to contracts, like loan with interest

arguments.claim: The amounts are not like those in Morley v. Tattersall which were not income

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri also referred us to Morley v. Pattersall and contended that the amounts with which we are concerned, were of the same kind as those considered in that case and were not income. It seems to us that there is no similarity between the two cases at all.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Wilfrid Greene said at p. 65 Mr. Hills argument was to the effect that, although they were number trading receipts at the moment of receipt, they had

arguments.court_reasoning: In Morley, receipts never trading receipts, held on behalf of others creating liability; here appellant's own moneys from start, part of trading with profit-making quality

arguments.claim: The collections described as empty bottle return security deposits were income assessable under section 10 of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the collections by the assessee company described in its accounts as empty bottle return security deposits were income assessable under section 10 of the Income-tax Act? The High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 65 to the effect that, The money which was received was money which had number got any profit making quality about it it was money which, in a busines

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed with High Court; amounts are trading receipts taxable as business income

arguments.claim: The quality and nature of a receipt for Income Tax purposes is fixed once and for all when it is received; supports they are trading receipts from receipt

anchor.surface_text: It seems to me that the quality and nature of a receipt for Income Tax purposes is fixed once and for all when it is received.

arguments.claim: Refundability of sums does not prevent them from being part of price, as bottle price was also refundable

anchor.surface_text: It is not contended that the fact that the additional sums might have to be refunded showed that they were not part of the price. It could not be so contended because what was expressly said to be the price of bottles and admitted to be price was also refundable.

holdings.text: the amounts paid to the appellant and described as Empty Bottles Return Security Deposit were trading receipts and therefore income of the appellant assessable to tax

anchor.surface_text: Having given the matter our anxious companysideration which the difficulties involved in it require, we think that the companyrect view to take is that the amounts paid to the appellant and described as Empty Bottles Return Security Deposit were trading receipts and therefore income of the appellant assessable to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amounts integral to each sale transaction as mandatory payment for bottled liquor supply; treated separately in accounts but substance over form; refundable but bottle price similarly refundable; no buyer obligation to return bottles negating security character; analogous to second period in Lakshmanier Sons as trading advance; distinguished from Shell Co (anterior deposits), Lakshmanier third period (loans), Morley (non-trading receipts); nature fixed upon receipt.

holdings.text: these additional sums appear to us to be its trading receipts... the amount which was called security deposit was actually a part of the consideration for the sale and therefore part of the price of what was sold

anchor.surface_text: Such being the nature of the appellants trade and the manner in which it was companyducted, these additional sums appear to us to be its trading receipts. ... So the amount which was called security deposit was actually a -part of the companysideration for the sale and therefore part of the price of what was sold.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trade consists of selling bottled liquor; no sale without payment of liquor price, govt bottle price, and additional sum; all form composite consideration; separate accounting or different refund timing irrelevant as substance determines tax nature.

holdings.text: There could be no security given for the return of the bottles unless there was a right to their return... The wholesalers were clearly under no obligation to return the bottles

anchor.surface_text: There companyld be numbersecurity given for the return of the bottles unless there was a right to their return for if there was numbersuch right, there would be numberhing to secure. Now we find numbertrace of such a right in the statement of the care. The wholesalers were clearly under numberobligation to return the bottles.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express right or obligation traced in facts; mere label 'security deposit' insufficient to impose duty; no time limit for return or refusal instances; if intended, bottles would be loaned not sold.

holdings.text: We must therefore on the authority of Lakshmanier Sons case, hold the amounts in the present case to have been trading receipts... we therefore think that the present case is governed by the arrangement covering the second period and come to the conclusion that the amounts with which we are concerned were trading receipts

anchor.surface_text: We must therefore on the authority of Laskhmanier Sons case, hold the amounts in the present case to have been trading receipts. It was Mr. Sastris effort to bring the case within the arrangement that prevailed in the third part of the accounting period in Laskhmanier Sons case, the initial payments made during which were held to be loans. But we think that he has number succeeded in this.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exact match to Lakshmanier second period: payment with each contract/sale, refundable on contract completion event (delivery/return), not borrowed money; differs from third period (once-for-all anterior deposit with interest, adjusted only on default at relation end).

holdings.text: what was a consideration for the sale cannot cease to be so by being written up in the books in a particular manner

anchor.surface_text: Nor does it make any difference that the price of the bottles was entered in the general trading account while the so called deposit was entered in a separate ledger termed empty bottles return deposit account , for, what was a companysideration for the sale cannot cease to be so by being written up in the books in a particular manner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal character determined by transaction substance, not accounting treatment; govt bottle price in trading account despite refundability confirms principle.

precedents.citation: Davies v. The Shell Company of China Ltd. 1951 32 Tax Cas. 133

anchor.surface_text: For this part of the case Mr. Sastri relied on Davies v. The Shell Company of China Ltd.  1 , but we do number think that case assists at all. What had happened there was that the Shell Company had appointed a large number of agents in China to sell its products  1   1951  32 Tax Cas. 133.

precedents.case_name: Davies v. The Shell Company of China Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: deposits made by agents to secure against default were not trading receipts as they were anterior to trading transactions
precedents.cited_holding: the deposits out of which it was made were really number trading receipts at all

precedents.citation: Landes Bros. v. Simpson 1934 19 Tax Cas. 62

anchor.surface_text: it If the agents deposit had in truth been a payment in advance to be applied by the Company in discharging the sums from time to time due from the agent in respect of petroleum products transferred to the agent and sold by him the case might well be different and might well fall within the ratio deciding of Landes Bros. v. Simpson  1  and Imperial Tobacco Co. v. Kelly  2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: advance payments applied to price of goods would be taxable trading receipts

precedents.citation: Imperial Tobacco Co. v. Kelly 1943 25 Tax Cas. 292

anchor.surface_text: We might also refer to the observationsmade in Imperial Tobacco Co. v. Kelly 1  mentioned in the Shell Company case  2  and set out below. There the Company in the companyrse of its trading activity used to purchase tobacco in America and for that purpose had to acquire American dollars.  1   1943  25 Tax Cas. 292.

precedents.cited_proposition: purchase of dollars for intended commercial transaction of buying tobacco was part of trading activity even if not completed
precedents.cited_holding: The purchase of the dollars was the first step in carrying out an intended companymercial transaction, namely, the purchase of tobacco leaf.

precedents.citation: K. M. S. Lakshmanier Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras 1953 S.C.R. 1057

anchor.surface_text: The case nearest to the present one is, in our view, that decided by this Court in K. M. S. Lakshmanier Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras  3 . There the appellants, who were the assessees, were merchants carrying on business as the sole selling agents for yarn manufactured by the Madura Mills Co. Ltd.  3   1953  S.C.R. 1057.

precedents.case_name: K. M. S. Lakshmanier Sons v. Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: initial payments or deposits made as part of sales contracts or in relation to specific contracts are trading receipts even if refundable on completion
precedents.cited_holding: they partake more of the nature of trading receipts than of security deposits
